title: Big bonuses breed bad behaviour, says Barclays chairman
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Oct 22, 2015, 22:34 BST - UK Markets closed Big bonuses breed bad behaviour, says Barclays chairman By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago 250.65 +2.60 
John McFarlane says he would scrap current bonus system for bankers and replace it with a scheme that rewards long-term performance 
Barclays (Swiss: BARC.SW - news ) ’ chairman believes investment bankers should not get huge bonuses, as they encourage bad behaviour and short-term thinking. 
John McFarlane said that in an ideal world he would like to see the current situation abolished and replaced with a longer-term system. 
However, as that is unlikely to happen, he said Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) will instead have to save money by working with as small a number of investment bankers as possible. 
“I used to run the markets side of various institutions and I was never paid anything close to anything people get paid in these areas now,” Mr McFarlane said, speaking at the British Bankers’ Association annual conference. 
“If I had my own way, and this can never happen, I would reward people at the end, once you know the results sometimes three or five years down the road. 
“At least you are then rewarding them for what you know in terms of the value they have created.” 
As the industry is dominated by high-paying US banks, however, he expects to keep paying bonuses in the current model. 
As a result, Barclays will have to cut jobs rather than pay as it tries to save money. 
“I don't think we can pay people less than the market price, and that implies that if you want to control costs, you want to operate with as few people as possible,” he said. 
Mr McFarlane refused to comment on whether or not he is hiring former JP Morgan executive Jes Staley as Barclays’ new chief executive . But when asked about the implications of hiring an investment banker for the top job, he denied that Mr Staley is an investment banker by trade. 
“He is not an investment banker. He started life like me, as a commercial banker, he is a corporate banker,” said Mr McFarlane. 
“He then ran the equities division, but he didn't trade equities. He ran the fund management division, and then ran the investment banking. He is a client guy, like I started life, lending money to corporations.” 
Barclays’ executive chairman also warned that the sustained flood of fines and the steady tide of regulation could hit bank lending and undermine the wider British economy. 
“I'm worried about the real economy effect of all of this. Years and years after the crisis we are still pushing water uphill in terms of increased regulation,” he said. 
“If we can't [move on from historic problems] then other countries will, and we will be relatively disadvantaged.”
